author: AleHaRotK
body:
?

If you bought Intel 5 years ago you're up like 30%, if you invested in AMD 5 years ago you're up 1400%.

Change that to a year, AMD you're up 50%, Intel you're **down** 1~2%.

All of this in a context where everything has skyrocketed... up 30% in 5 years when everything else is up a lot more is pretty bad. I get that's what "value" means but so far it hasn't been the best play.

author: Redditsome22
body:
[Pie graph](https://ibb.co/wwc9QhN?fbclid=IwAR1z1gj0gQ7T8nUUHXUVERiWjmndFdjXWnYv6Y-Y_BAsgDVGgiYFoKHRegU)

&#x200B;

I have done a lot of repositioning into positions currently on what I considered a discount all of those flew high, too fast and burnt to the ground and beyond. went deep into BABA - currently 178avg and PYPL 211 avg - currently sadly sitting at an unrealized xx% loss. Also loaded on what was a speculative position last year with higher conviction now - bought quite a few CRSP at what I believe to be the bottom at the 78 range - currently avg at 102+-.{Not even mentioning my stupid PLTR,BB position - gambles going wrong atm, believing in the hype and the reason I bought hasnt changed still hence why i havent sold}  
  
Although I have sizeable losses here these positions have elevated my positions amazingly.  
  
Holding a sizeable position with xxx% returns on AMD and NIO and very bullish on SE - recently added to my position at 280  
  
bought into the AMC hype with a 14 avg and sold of 80% at around the 60 mark  
  
  
  
Square shouldve been scalped and rebought 205-280 range and back is ridiculous but oh well  
  
sold JD into strenght to buy into my weaker positions - had a big position before. still bullish but seeing more upside elsewhere atm.  
  
I dont have any us mega caps- I know winners stay winners usually but I am looking for hopefully bigger returns albeith I run risk of big losses, clearly, as well - such as sizeble position in a clinical trial biotech AGTC - currently at a big loss aswell but that was expected. Lets see what happens here. stock at all time lows.  
  
  
  
for example although im sitting at a 10avg with my SKLZ position the downside is limited here imo, and potential huge hence why I have been adding to my position lately a lot bellow 10  
  
  
  
I do recommend people look into CPNG and let me know their thoughts. I am torn between adding to this position or keeping it small.

author: CamSlam2902
body: No the growth stocks in this market are based revenue projections and what their potential to grow into is. This constant complaining about the market is just draining. In the last round of earnings it’s been shown for the growth stocks that if there’s a miss on revenue or concerns about meeting growth in revenue there is sharp drops in stock price to reflect. Nvda and amd are no different to this a miss in revenue would tank the stock. If you want to value invest and your valuation tells you that intel is under priced you go for it. But intel isn’t for me could even hit targets last earnings while demand for semiconductors is high while just about every other companies makes fat bags. Any how su bae guiding us what’s the worst that can happen will have bigger problems if the market collapses.

author: Desmater
body:
Energy
Companies not investing into capex but lowering debt, buybacks and dividends. Current prices of $70-85 let's then throw off FCF to buy 10-20% of the float.

Banks and insurance
Higher rates and overall good economy. They have ton of FCF for buybacks and dividend increases. Plus cash to start lending and other investments.

Steel
Steel prices have never been better. EVs, infrastructure and Airplanes need steel. More and more of the world is flying now and growing still. Car makers should start getting chips to restart production. Infrastructure bill in US. EV charging stations will need it. Telecoms need to push 5G globally.

Big Tech
They will always be growing.

Semiconductors
More and more things need semis. I would buy most of them. TXN, QCOM, MRVL, AMD, INTC, NVDA, UMC, TSMC, etc.

author: ryan7714
body:
Jim Cramer Trims AMD, Refuses To Sell Any Nvidia Stock: Here's Why

12/1/21, 12:00
December 1, 2021 01:00 PM ET (BZ Newswire) -- Long Ideas

Advanced Micro Devices Inc (NASDAQ:AMD) is up more than 70% year-to-date, so Jim Cramer decided to lock in profits and trim his position.

"We are trimming AMD this morning solely for portfolio management purposes and not out of any change to our bullish long-term view of the company," Cramer said Wednesday in a letter to members of CNBC's "Investing Club."

He noted that he purchased AMD stock in February and is realizing an 80% gain by selling shares today.

See Also: Check Out What Whales Are Doing With AMD

Despite citing prudent portfolio management as the reason for trimming AMD, Cramer said he refuses to sell any shares of NVIDIA Corp (NASDAQ:NVDA), which is up more than 150% year-to-date.

"I'm being a pig in Nvidia," Cramer said Wednesday on CNBC. "Because this may be a $10 trillion stock."

AMD, NVDA Price Action: At publication time, AMD was down 0.93% at $156.84, while Nvidia was up 0.35% at $328.05.

author: DarthTrader357
body:
Nope. A lot of people shjt on me for putting too low of a target on AMD because I wanted it at say $95 and it never hit $95. Instead it broke my thesis and shot up to its present $155.

But it was correctly in a channel before the momentum swing and there's a swing trader named Kristian Qullamaggie who executes exactly that type of trade. I bet you he was in on AMD.

The thesis is a channel for 2-8 weeks = a possible momentum swing. 

After blowing up his account several times he is on record of turning $9,000 into $80,000,000 in 5 years.

Yes that's true.

That being said, AMD and the broader market noise.

AMD, regarding momentum and one-time-framing are often pretty correlated.

It isn't guaranteed there will be a half back.

But the momentum stalled and confirmed in the last week. Well before the noise.

So basing on the psychological reasons of the half back...the general reason it exists is smart traders do 2 things. 

1) tight stops.
2) identify a point of control.

Dumb traders do 2 things.

1) no stops.
2) FOMO.

The super smart traders short this pattern.

So what ends up happening is the trade stalls, the stops are put on. Then a catalyst (today's sell off let's say) triggers stops.

Shorts smell blood and pile on the shorts which adds selling pressure.

Dumb traders watch their gains evaporate.

FOMO buyers watch their hopes and dreams turn to shjt in their mouth.

So bottom line is the whole stage is set for a rebalancing around the point of control. Where people who sat out the first run see opportunity. 

So you can see that in general the psychology makes a lot of sense. 

Today's market issues are largely irrelevant. 

If it wasn't this, it will have been something else.

Because the pattern emerges over a weekly time frame. 

What this suggests is the people with the most money are trading AMD weekly...slowly (relatively).

They see it stall and they wait. They have their stops tight and they are cautious to see what happens next.

Since they are slow...the stock lingers. Pushes out a couple weeks.

If it pushes longer it could mean there's actually good support. New customers (buyers) willing to come in and buy at the new price.

The sharp down week and we are midweek, suggests to me we have a good chance it's going to half back.

It'll trigger stops. Panic sells. And Shorters described above.

That's why if the market is up tomorrow you definitely want to pay attention to what AMD does. It basically has to trade in tandem with the market.

Anything weaker. And next week might be the drop.

body:
Jim Cramer Trims AMD, Refuses To Sell Any Nvidia Stock: Here's Why

12/1/21, 12:00
December 1, 2021 01:00 PM ET (BZ Newswire) -- Long Ideas

Advanced Micro Devices Inc (NASDAQ:AMD) is up more than 70% year-to-date, so Jim Cramer decided to lock in profits and trim his position.

"We are trimming AMD this morning solely for portfolio management purposes and not out of any change to our bullish long-term view of the company," Cramer said Wednesday in a letter to members of CNBC's "Investing Club."

He noted that he purchased AMD stock in February and is realizing an 80% gain by selling shares today.

See Also: Check Out What Whales Are Doing With AMD

Despite citing prudent portfolio management as the reason for trimming AMD, Cramer said he refuses to sell any shares of NVIDIA Corp (NASDAQ:NVDA), which is up more than 150% year-to-date.

"I'm being a pig in Nvidia," Cramer said Wednesday on CNBC. "Because this may be a $10 trillion stock."

AMD, NVDA Price Action: At publication time, AMD was down 0.93% at $156.84, while Nvidia was up 0.35% at $328.05.

author: DarthTrader357
body:
Nope. A lot of people shjt on me for putting too low of a target on AMD because I wanted it at say $95 and it never hit $95. Instead it broke my thesis and shot up to its present $155.

But it was correctly in a channel before the momentum swing and there's a swing trader named Kristian Qullamaggie who executes exactly that type of trade. I bet you he was in on AMD.

The thesis is a channel for 2-8 weeks = a possible momentum swing. 

After blowing up his account several times he is on record of turning $9,000 into $80,000,000 in 5 years.

Yes that's true.

That being said, AMD and the broader market noise.

AMD, regarding momentum and one-time-framing are often pretty correlated.

It isn't guaranteed there will be a half back.

But the momentum stalled and confirmed in the last week. Well before the noise.

So basing on the psychological reasons of the half back...the general reason it exists is smart traders do 2 things. 

1) tight stops.
2) identify a point of control.

Dumb traders do 2 things.

1) no stops.
2) FOMO.

The super smart traders short this pattern.

So what ends up happening is the trade stalls, the stops are put on. Then a catalyst (today's sell off let's say) triggers stops.

Shorts smell blood and pile on the shorts which adds selling pressure.

Dumb traders watch their gains evaporate.

FOMO buyers watch their hopes and dreams turn to shjt in their mouth.

So bottom line is the whole stage is set for a rebalancing around the point of control. Where people who sat out the first run see opportunity. 

So you can see that in general the psychology makes a lot of sense. 

Today's market issues are largely irrelevant. 

If it wasn't this, it will have been something else.

Because the pattern emerges over a weekly time frame. 

What this suggests is the people with the most money are trading AMD weekly...slowly (relatively).

They see it stall and they wait. They have their stops tight and they are cautious to see what happens next.

Since they are slow...the stock lingers. Pushes out a couple weeks.

If it pushes longer it could mean there's actually good support. New customers (buyers) willing to come in and buy at the new price.

The sharp down week and we are midweek, suggests to me we have a good chance it's going to half back.

It'll trigger stops. Panic sells. And Shorters described above.

That's why if the market is up tomorrow you definitely want to pay attention to what AMD does. It basically has to trade in tandem with the market.

Anything weaker. And next week might be the drop.
